ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 3-4 hours
4-6 on average
Roughly 2-3 hours/week was dedicated for case analysis or readings. An average of 3 hours/week was dedicated for group presentations.
4-8 hours
5, more for group projects
2/wk regular, 10/wk for cases, 15/wk groups
two hours per week.
2-3hours Readings7-11 hours -Case Work and Projects
Approximately 2 on normal weeks and much more when we had an assignment due (maybe 5 - 10 hours for presentations and 24 hours for the written assignment)

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: -The case method is good, but incredibly repetitive. I think there should be 2-3 fewer cases supplemented with in class discussion of non-cases and/or more frequent guest lectures from actual healthcare managers.-The workload was fine, but again, fairly repetitive. I don't think writing up two cases is twice as good as writing up one case. In fact, I don't think writing up cases really adds much value at all. I understand the concept, but the cases do not always connect and so I don't feel that I'm leaving this class with the the skills that I would need as a healthcare manager.-We spent a lot of time on the insurance business and hospitals and almost none on pharmaceuticals, tech, private practice, etc.
Perhaps more cases outisde the context of hospitals

The course was good..Liked the manner the class was conducted.. Lot of discussions.. facilitated thinking out of the box..the class had a good way of tying theoretical management concepts to healthcare and then li linking to the cases..The presentation opportunity at midterm and finals was a tremendous learning.
Best course I have taken! Loved the broad range of topics.

A comprehensive ending for the health management program that included analysis across the healthcare industry (e.g. case studies in hospitals, insurance, etc.)Strengths: In-depth case analysis. Opportunities to apply managerial frameworks (e.g. RCA, SWOT analysis).Weaknesses: Despite a comprehensive view of the healthcare industry, more focus was placed on hospital cases. A more consistent distribution may be more beneficial for students graduating into other sectors.
This course is great! The structure, the workload, and the assignments were all very good. I did not feel like my time was wasted at any point.
very interesting and practical; fun discussion in class

I thought the course was great and really essential to a lot of the issues that came up in my interviews for jobs. The only thing I'd prefer is a broader application of these issues represented in the cases- eg not just hospitals.

This is the best course I have taken at YSPH. It is extremely organized and there is a different case with a unique focus each week. I really liked the mix of students in the class - it provided for a good discussion each week. I appreciated that the syllabus contained prep questions each week, so we knew what to focus on when reading. I also thought Ingrid's wrap up at the end of each class to cover broader topics and the other readings was very helpful. Talking to other students in the class, the only thing that I can come up with to be improved upon is having more cases that aren't hospital focused. "Healthcare Organizations" covers a wide range of entities but only 1 or 2 of the cases we had this year were outside of the hospital world.
enjoyed case study format
Strength: Cases based, selected cases are very representative, relevant to every aspects of health care delivery. Active in-class discussion.
This class is an amazing wrap up of the HMP program/curriculum. Dr Nembhard is a thorough and very competent professor who teaches with amazing grace, style and has set up a very comprehensive course
It was a great course. Good Cases. Great hospital management lessons. Great Instructor.

This is a good class. Its primary strength is that it integrates the other courses that make up the Health Management curriculum. The format starts to wear toward the later 3rd of the class, though, making the last few sessions feel less engaging/challenging.
Excellent course with great cases and structure to classroom discussions.

Excellent choice of case studies and material - I would have appreciated more variety beyond hospital cases but still, excellent. Informative discussions, excellent readings and ppt presentations from the faculty. The only thing I would add to the course is perhaps a little more focus on practical analytic tools such as financial analysis etc. during the class case study discussions.
Very good management course for non-management students.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  -Ingrid was a very well organized professor. I did not connect very well with her and didn't find her to be particularly helpful outside of class but in class she was excellent. She clearly has a very solid understanding of the material and takes the course very seriously. It would be good if she waswilling to go the extra mile in mentoring students, especially for the capstone experience.
Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Perky.. friendly.. energetic...facilitated thinking... was good facilitator.. Her class slides are valuable.. could be used even later..

Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Ingrid is GREAT! HMP is SO lucky to have her! Her manner in addressing the class is so wonderful and engaging.The material she covers is wonderful and her slides will be a reference for years to come. I site material learned outside of class all the time!
Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Very knowledgeable, approachable, and able to tease insights from students. A model YSPH teacher.

Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Ingrid is an excellent communicator, an engaging teacher, and a passionate academic. She is very pleasant, yet stern and strives to get her students to think outside the box.
Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  great teaching style and very well-spoken
Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Ingrid was really supportive and did a great job encouraging students to think rather than spit out a generic answer

Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Ingrid is excellent and a perfect professor for this course because she is engaging and encourages participation without being annoying. She knew the name of everyone in the class by the second or third week. I have had some professors twice and I still don't think they know my name. Being in the Health Policy&Administration track, I thought I was going to have to fight to get into this class, so I was thrilled when Ingrid sent all of the 2nd-year HPA students an email inviting us to check out the class during reading week. The feedback on the two group assignments and two individual assignments was extremely thorough and some of the most detailed I've received at Yale. Also, Ingrid invited Cleve Killingsworth to speak to our class. He is definitely one of the best speakers I've seen at Yale and I really appreciated that it was such a small venue because I got even more out of it.
Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Smart and good at teaching.
Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Organized; very thorough; prompt in response; very available;
Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Great teaching material. Clear class agenda. Great for feedback and assessment.

Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Professor Nembhard is a great, enthusiastic teacher. She is clearly committed to her students and her material, however she rarely seems to deviate from pre-planned lessons. A bit of flexibility might make some classes more engaging and less formulaic.

Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Ingrid was just FANTASTIC. She was engaging, empathetic, knowledgeable and approachable. One thing that I think would be really helpful is more criticism over students' in class comments.

Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Knowledgeable and engaging, she obviously loves teaching and it comes through. Takes her work seriously and is truly dedicated to helping students learn. One area of improvement could be avoiding to give the impression that students are held to different standards, I think this may not be the case but some students may have felt this way.
Instructor: Ingrid Marie Nembhard  Highly enthusiastic and engaging. Makes learning a very active and interactive process. Great use of practical examples.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Christina was great. She answer questions promptly and was always very nice and very helpful in class. I wish she had gotten to present on Coca Cola in Tanzania!
Christina is helpful... answered all the queries.. streamlined a lot unclarity... helpful overall..
The TA was very courteous to hold a workshop on how to properly analyze case studies.
Christina was very nice but I did not have much interaction with her.
responsible

Christina Yuan was great. She attended every class, so we knew who she was. I emailed her a number of times asking specific questions about assignments and she was also very responsive. She also helped organize everything during group presentation days, which made things move smoothly.
Very nice and helpful.
great TA who is very accessible
Very helpful.
Christina was a fabulous and accessible TA, even when she was extremely swamped/busy or she was approached last minute.
I didn't have much interaction with the TA so am not qualified to give much feedback, but she appears nice and was a fair grader.
Christina is always very willing to assist with any questions. Enjoyed having her as a TA.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: You'll read a lot of HBS cases, get a lot out of them, and then experience diminishing returns as the semester progresses. I would probably not recommend it to a student who did not have to take the class. I don't think I gained very concrete skills.
good course..definitely recommend it
We are lucky to have this course included in the curriculum. If it weren't required, I would say it should be!
Yes, a strong primer course for students entering the health management field.
A great course on leadership and managing organizations. I would recommend ALL MPH divisions to take the course.
a must take for everyone who is interested management or hospital adm

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially if that student is in Health Policy but much more interested in the operational side of things (as opposed to high-level theoretical topics covered by the Policy Capstone). The case-based structure of the classes and the 4 assignments give you real world examples and practical skills that we can actually apply. I even talked about one of the cases in a job interview. The 4 assignments are a lot of work (especially coordinating with your team for the 2 group projects), but I got a lot out of them, especially because of the detailed feedback we got. Ingrid is awesome and dedicated to making this class the best it can be, so I can only see it getting better.
Big YES!Strength: Cases based, selected cases are very representative, relevant to every aspects of health care delivery. Active in-class discussion.
this is the best class of the entire HMP program. very comprehensive
I would recommend the course. Great capstone

This is a good class. Its primary strength is that it integrates the other courses that make up the Health Management curriculum. The format starts to wear toward the later 3rd of the class, though, making the last few sessions feel less engaging/challenging.
Excellent course for anyone wanting to enter health care leadership in any way shape or form. Brings science and credibility to organizational behaviour theories and concepts.
Absolutely recommended. This is one of the YSPH courses where you actually learn a lot and are actively engaged throughout the semester.
Excellent course to take. It gives you an insight into real world issues of health care organization management, helps to work your way to find a solution.
